Entry.1:
New Year’s Day –

A Happy, Bright & Peaceful New Year to friends & enemies – Our Hall graced by the Gen. Sir Wm Birdwood who shakes with one & all after the show and is mighty pleased with his Concert Party – General Coxon also present.
Entry.2:
Two Australian Letters received. A strange coincidence concerning one – Our Panto has a most disastrous ending this evening – A fire takes place in the engine room & two engineers are badly burned

 

Jan.3rd (14)

News of Herb Marl Hammy & Fred being in England – Engine again fails during the Panto. – Letter No.14 written – "A pin that was missing during a juggling act."
Entry.3:
Letters to Home & Scotland.

Jan.5th

Last show in Sheenwerck -. Most successful night of Panto – English troops now in Sheenwerck –Anzacs depart. Again meet Mr. Hewett.

Jan.6th

Fatigue duties at Theatre – Preparing for departure from Sheenwerck – Cyril & self have most enjoyable stroll to Bac.St & are entertained by friends made early in "1916" – Stopped "en route" by a guard, & we overcame the difficulty.

Jan.7th

Our advance party leaves for Bailleul with Panto. Props & scenery.- 

Germans Peace conference unsuccessful owing to non-appearance of Russian Delegates.
Entry.4: Early rise – Pack up & Load Lorries – leave Sheenwerck, which proved to be safest town in which we have had the pleasure of showing – Arrive at Bailleul 11 a.m. (last in this town in
Entry.5:
Afternoon spent in preparing Hall & Stage for Panto. – For first time in France I become the proud possessor of a Private Billet.

Jan.9th

Two Heavy snowfalls – Day duties in the Hall – At night we again produce

Panto with great success – Major Churchill congratulates "Coves," and speaks of a tour which is being arranged by General Birdwood.-

Jan.10th

Memories of Bailleul
Entry.6:
Skittle alley – Visit to Y.M.C.A. Book from Library – Afternoon spent sewing & writing Large mail from Australia.

Jan.11th

Mess Purchases – rehearsal – "Tales of Mystery & Imagination". Earl of Cassiles (Town Major –) Mild weather. Panto still booming.

Jan.12th

Receive Birthday Parcel from Home – "Mystery & Imagination" – Again meet Mr. Jack Kirby – Votes granted to the Women of England.

Jan.13th

My 21st Birthday – Genuine congratulations & Good wishes from my Pals – A special Dinner for the occasion (Soup, chicken, ham, vegetables, fruit salad, ginger etc.) –

Letters containing Birthday greetings from Australia arrive right on time – A glorious day –

Correspondence 

 

Jan.14th

Rehearsal & Show – Fall of snow.

Jan.15th 

Second anniversary of departure from Sydney – Receive cable from Home containing Birthday Wishes – I meet Charlie Heydon – News of George Martin – "Mauvaes Temp.—
Entry.7:
Change of Programme – Welcome return to – "Sphinx & Woman" – British air reprisals – Russia still undecided – Beau coup correspondence – Comfort increases in our Billet 

Jan.17th

Rehearsal & show – "Tennyson’s Suppressed Poems" – after two years I again have great pleasure in meeting George Martin – Mess Purchases –
Entry.8: Trouble in the Camp (H.Q.) – Completion of Elocution Notes – A.F.C. & their splendid work. – Show minus two numbers "East Lynne"
Entry.9:
Madame’s kindness – Mail from Australia (Mother’s "51") Letters also from M.B. S.C. – E.B – C.C. 

Afternoon spent with George Martin and evening (including supper) with Harry – I write a sketch (or is it an apology) entitled "Failed to Start"
Entry.10: Sabbath – Pay day – Reading & Writing – We journey in the evening to Steenge (?) where we give a show to
Entry.11:
Batt. (3rd Div. Artillery) arriving back at Ballieul late in the night.

Jan.21st.

Lloyd George says "Fight On! – Change of Programme – Letter to M.B. "Les Miserables"- Fred Reade in Paris.
Entry.12:
Goeben & Breslau smashed by British – Probable effect on Turkey – Mess Purchases – New numbers & sketches rehearsed.

Letter "No 17" to Mother.
Entry.13: "Les Miserables – Correspondence – Algie returns from Hospital – 16th Battalion Band is attached to our party, & provide good music.
Entry.14:
Change of Programme. – General Brand once more

a patron – Tribute paid to the "Coves" by Officers & Men of R.F.C.

Mild weather – Packed Houses continue.

Jan.25th

Enquiry in London regarding the Cambrae Offensive – "Les Miserables" continues to instruct & interest me. Study of Othello’s speech on the "Wooing of Desdemona".
Entry.15:
Australian Anniversary Day – I meet, converse with, and am conferred a favour by Capt. Austin (10th Aust. F.Amb.) – "Les Miserables" & "Othello"

Cont:

Measurements for new costumes – Ordering of new Sketches – Afternoon & Evening spent with George Martin – Pleasant memories &’ delightful reminiscences.
Entry.16:
(No.18)

Sabbath.

Letter writing & Reading – Afternoon & Evening spent at
Entry.17:
F.Amb where we give a "complimentary show to the Boys" – Return to Bailleul.

Jan.28th.

Change of Program – Fred Reade & self "go big" with "Burglar & the Girl"

After the show – A few of us spend the Evening with Officers & Boys of
Entry.18:
A.S.C. (H.Q.) A very merry & happy night – Majors dancing with Privates etc. I meet, and gain the true news of the Cambrai reverse from Capt. Manchester – 

Jan.29th (No.52)

During the day I meet Alex Saxton & Sid Brown – Nov.25th Letters from Home (Receipt of my own letters 1.2.3.4.& 5). Another letter from Herb – "Les Miserables" Cpl. Bower returns from London Harry leaves for Paris. 

Jan.30th.

British Air Raids on German Towns – During the day I meet Madame’s daughter (age, about 45) and other of Madame’s friends – Political Unrest in Germany & Austria.
Entry.19:
Change of Programme – "Fuzzy Wuzzy" – strikes in Germany- War rationing in England – In a leisure half hour I run across a gold mine in the shape of a shop containing Shakespeare – Homer. Dickens – Tennyson & Kipling etc –

Weather colder.
Entry.20:
– 1918

Feb.1st

A day of days – Major Churchill returns from London with the news that on 

Feb.11th we are to open at the Court Theatre" London. – Letter despatched to Mr. Fitz. "re cable to Dad – German Air raid on Paris – Martial Law in Germany with regard to strikers –

Tennysons Poems.
Entry.21:
Rehearsal & show (as usual) – German agitators arrested – Another of 

Madame’s sons returns to Bailleul on Furlough (10 days every 4 months) – Letter written to the Boys.
Entry.22:
Sabbath – Letter writing – Pay day – In the Afternoon I meet Billy Stewart – At night we journey "per" motor lorry to St. Jans Coppell where we entertain the 9th Corp School of Tommies – Great appreciation of our efforts.

Feb.4th 

Change of Programme – Meet Bobby Davis (from Baths at Balmain – After evening 

Performance (in which I do well with "Sari Bair") we are tendered a farewell Evening by Officers & Men of
Entry.23: A.S.C. - Nero once again has a downfall – likewise a fall down – Bed at 2 a.m.
Entry.24:
Major McKenzie, Lt. Rowe,. Major Parmer. Capt Ramsay A.P.M. etc.

Feb.5th

Packing up for London – Last night of the "Anzac Coves" in Bailleul – A fitting conclusion to a most successful run – Meet Jack Neal. With George Martin once again.

Feb.6th

More packing, & loading of Lorry – Storage of properties etc. – First detachment of the Coves (6 in number) leave for London – Cinema only at Theatre – A pleasant evening (first time off duty for months) during which we converse with & are given supper by Madame.
Entry.27:
Final preparations – Bid Madame adieu, and in company with Jack Shaw, I entrain at Bailleul Station, loaded with personal & theatrical goods – arrive Calais 2.30 p.m. but 
fail
 to board "packet" at 5.15 p.m. for Dover. Pass night in Calais.
Entry.28:
Feb.10th.

Embark at 8.30 a.m. – a rough trip across the Channel. Arrive at Dover & entrain for London – Arrive Victoria & taxi to War Chest – thence to Court Theatre & then back to War Chest – At night. 

I see Gladys Cooper in the "Yellow Ticket" - Return to & sleep at War Chest.
Entry.29:
Sabbath spent in long & efficient rehearsal – I procure a private billet. Bus & taxi drives.

Monday. Feb.12th.

Amid great anxiety but "undaunted courage" the Anzac Coves appear for first time in London. – a small house does not promise much success but we do exceptionally well – "Sari Bair" brings only encore – Broken Bottles (?) The evening 

 

performance carries audience by storm. Despite our custom of never taking encores two or three of us are compelled to do so. – Supper at Trocadero – Congratulations from Sir Ian Hamilton & Lady Birdwood.
Entry.30:
Feb.12th

Visit A.C.F. & see Mr Henley – Correspondence & diary at War Chest – Meet Jack Dunn at Matinee, after which Jack so kindly takes me to the residence of Mr. & Mrs. Scales at Hornsey Lane, Highgate Hill. – A beau

tiful Home which is only excelled by the Kindness & hospitality of Host & Hostess – Farewell to Jack who leaves for Australia in the morning. Evening show a huge success (After this entertainment I meet & converse with Mr & Mrs. Chilton & invited to their Home.
Entry.31:
Visit War Chest – Letters. Meet Sid Laird – Lunch. Return to Court Theatre – Matinee, after which I meet Fred Shutchbury & receive great news from Herb.

Evening entertainment under the patronage of Princess Alice. General Cockson etc – More congratulations & bouquets. A request from General & Lady Hamilton – Prospects of touring Scotland.
Entry.32:
London’s System of Tubes – Partial change makes programme stronger – Heavy work for self – Houses bigger & more enthusiastic – More paper notices – Fred & I score well with "Burglar Sketch" – "Singing Soldiers" Eddie Cornish present at night show.

Meet Mr. Ayres – Dinner with Miss Chilton – meet Mr. & Mrs. Copper.
Entry.33:
Feb.15th

Letters to Mother & C.H. – Another request for Sari Bair – A successful matinee at which Herb & Marl are present – Later we join Hammy, and the quartette have a great Dinner, a great Talk & many laughs at the Shaftesbury Hotel – The Boys are all Fit & Happy – Herb more funny than ever – Night show proves

most successful – Hammy misses "first Stage" to Dublin – "Sari Bair" & "The Tent.
Entry.34:
Wire to Edinburgh. Phone Mr Fitz – Correspondence – Miss Fitz & Miss Chilton both at Matinee & Evening shows – Dinner at Pelloni’s

Leicester Sg.) – German Air Raid interrupts latter part of show – Pack up for Weymouth.
Entry.35:
Leave boarding house at Sloane Sq.

Visit War Chest then on to Highgate Hill (Mr. & Mrs Scales) a charming, sincere & kind hearted Lady. Mr. Scales a benevolent, pious & sterling Gentleman – "Home Sweet Home" – Meet Arthur Brooker (48th Batt. A.I.F.) who also is a guest of Mrs. Scales. An Interesting afternoon walk over Highgate Hill etc During which we enter House of Nell Gwynne – I see the Home of Richard Cromwell and the House in which Bacon died after performing experiment with the "snow" etc.

(Home of Grand Duke Michael of Russia)

Visit "Wood Green" & Miss Chilton & Her People – Another "air raid’ & a late return to Highgate. Mrs. Scales repeated kindnesses.
Entry.36:
Feb. 18h

A morning visit to Buckingham Palace to make preparations for afternoon – At 5 p.m. the "Anzac Coves" have the supreme theatrical honour of Entertaining by Royal Command the King Queen, Prince of Wales & Princess Mary – together with many more

of the English Nobility – The King congratulates the Boys & makes most complimentary remarks –

The Throne Room

Court Ball Room

Reception Room etc. all come under our surveyance – Souvenir autographed photos given to us by King & Queen – Evening news reporter – and how he gained admittance very successful with "Sari Bair" – Returns to Highgate – 

Diary & Correspondence – 

Mrs. Samuels –
Entry.37:
Rise 10.30 – Bath & and Breakfast. Report to Horseferry Road – Met Jack Carey, who is minus a leg – Taxi to Waterloo – take 2 p.m. train to Weymouth. Pass through Guildford – Southampton. Bournemouth etc Destination 6.30 p.m. We are taken to Weymouth (A.I.F. Convalescent Camp) – "Back to the Army Again – (?) – Visit Jubilee Theatre and witness a very poor local show Return to Camp.

Feb.20th

Breakfast – Walk into Weymouth – Lunch in town 

at 2.30 p.m. we show to 1,800 people (Civilians & soldiers). The most enthusiastic show since coming to England. – Y.M.C.A. Letter writing.
Entry.38:
Morning trip "per" train to Island of Portland – We are shown the interior of Portland Gaol, which is garrisoned by Australian – Glorious Panoramas – Exhilarating atmosphere – Directly below the lofty emience of the prison ground lies the ocean, on whose waters are numerous sea planes & submarines – while 

(Colonels Wife)

The shore is bristling with guns – Return to Weymouth by Car. Afternoon show eclipses yesterday’s performance – Congratulations & tears by Ethel Warwick – Meet Edmund Sherras & Sgt. McBean – both bound for Australia – Return by Rail to London – Arrive Waterloo after midnight – Sleep at Peel House.
Entry.39:
A search for Herb & Mare proves unsuccessful – Mr. Henley – Renewal of leave Warrant – Return to Elm Bank – Like "Tipper

ary" my Heart’s right there", while in England. Mail from Home – Evening show at Southall Hospital – Meet Morrie – Return to Highgate.
Entry.40:
Rise late in the morning – Night show at Harefield declared off – Go to "Duke of Yorks" & see the famous Mrs Patrick Campbell in the "13th Chair. A play of Tragedy & Mystery wonderfully produced. Purchased books Army & Navy Stores – Back to the best spot in London – Evening 

spent most enjoyably with Mr & Mrs Scales amp; friends. Miss Marjorie Bedells.
Entry.41: Rise early. Go to Sloane Square to collect laundry etc – Luncheon at Elm Bank – Travel to Finchley Road to see Mr & Miss Fitzsimons – Return to War Chest Club & give entertainment during which we experience our fourth London Air Raid.
Entry.42:
Book seats for Theatre. Visits to War Chest Club – Aust. Comforts Club to Saony Studios (New Bond St.)– Taxi

to Sarony Studios (New Bond St) Anzac Coves Photographed – Waymouth Papers. Mrs Scales, Arthur & Myself see Charles Hawtrey in "The Saving Grace" (Haddon Chamberts. Very good – Distinctive & Natural Acting – Return to Elm Bank – "The Beauty & Charm of English Girls – The huge majority are attractive & captivating but – (here I pause & think of one sweet face in Australia) –

Wire to Edinburgh – Another musical evening. Leave Elm Bank & journey to King’s Cross where I

leave for Edinburgh by 10.30 p.m. train – A dreary night.

Feb.26th 

Arrive Waverley Station Edinburgh – Old & familiar scenes. Put up at Old Waverley Hotel. – At mid-day I meet my dear little Scotch friend – Afternoon spent in writing – shopping etc – Movies at night (Mary Pickford)

Feb.27th 

Diary & letters – again meet Jack Carey. – A quiet but enjoyable evening spent at 59 Brunswick St – Home of my friend.
Entry.43:
Still enjoying Peace & Quietness – Purchases of many Books for my next soujourn in France – Being pressed into a game of snooker by an Edinburgh gentleman in our Hotel – a New Zealand Corporal & myself have two easy victories - I surprise myself by doing all the scoring – Entertained by Miss Hater. – At night I witness my first Opera, which is "Tales of Hoffmann" by Carl Rosa Grand Opera Company.

March – 1918
Entry.44: Letters – Book Purchases. Edinburgh Hill – Movies – Another happy evening at the Home of my "friend" – Scotch Hospitality – The short stories of O’Henry and their possibilities as regards "dramatisation".
Entry.45: Late breakfast – Letters written & received – Afternoon – Evening spent in a quiet, but most enjoyable manner, in an easy chair before a Scotch fire place
Entry.46:
Harry Elliot & self have a pleasant morning walk down & under the Dean Bridge & Gardens – In the afternoon an Australian (in company with a Lassie) set out for Crammond – a grand walk in which much picturesque scenery is encountered – The & the Ocean.

Returned Edinburgh.
Entry.47:
Letters written & received – "Poems of Sentiment" (Wilcox) – O. Henry’s – Last day in Edinburgh – Evening spent at "59".

Brunswick St. – Sad partings – a weary train journey to London.
Entry.48:
Arrive "Kings’ Cross" 7.30 a.m. Train to Crouch End – Return to "Elm Bank" –Home Again. Meet Mr. & Mrs Matthews – Afternoon trip to London on business – a heart to heart talk with Mrs Scales – Correspondence.

Mar.6th 

Feeling ill – Breakfast 11 a.m. – A run into Town – Spend afternoon at Coliseum.

Seeing amongst others Ellen Terry – Bransby Williams – Florence Smithson- Return to Highgate – Meet Mrs Wm. Scales – Pay a call to Dr. Bousefield – with a sore throat. Correspondence – The night on which –

Mar.7th 

Meet Fred Reade in Town – Together we go to Daly’s Theatre & meet Mr. Todd (Actor & Manager) then on to Samuel French’s where we select Plays & Sketches – Return to Highgate. In the evening 

I take Mrs. Scales to Drury Lane where we witness & hear "Cavalleria & Pagliacci (Beecham Grand Opera Company) – Rosena Buckman, Robert Parker, Frank Mullings, Jeanne Brola the most important of a "great cast" – glorious singing – splendid acting – the Old & Historical Drury Lane Theatre – On our return journey to Elm Bank we are held up in the Tube for 3 hours owing to German Air Raid.
Entry.49:
Go to Town with Mrs.

Scales- Call on Mr. Scales at his Office – Then we view St. Giles Church 

(Cripplegate) which is burial place of Milton etc.etc. – Also played prominent part in Great Plague & Fire of London – Luncheon – Take train at Cannon St for Blackheath and go to the Home of Mrs.Thomas (Mrs.Scales’ Mother) – Pass most enjoyable evening with Mrs. Thomas – Mr. & Mrs Thomas (Jun) Miss Matthews, Mrs. Scales, Miss – Stay at Blackheath for the night.

Mar.9th

Return from Blackheath to Town – I view the interior & exterior of Houses of Parliament. Most interesting (see "Guide") – Luncheon – In the afternoon Mrs. Scales & myself witness the finest show I have yet been fortunate enough to see in my life – It is "Dear Brutus" – written by J.M. Barrie & played by Gerald du Maurier & Co.- Mr. du Maurier becomes (in one play) my favourite Actor – God Bless Him! – Still stage struck – Evening spent Mr & Mrs Wm Scales 

-Night Also.
Entry.50:
On Sunday morning Mr Wm Scales & self go strolling – "Parliament Hill – Hampstead Heath etc. – The strange but common sight of "Garden Plots" amp; "their workers".

Return to my home at "Elm Bank – Murray Sinclair visits us in afternoon – Evening spent with Mr. & Mrs. Harold Scales – Their two "sweet & pretty children". Return Elm Bank 11 p.m.

Mar.11th

Our stay in England extended at least a month – Needless to say we are all very sorry to hear the news. Read "From School to Stage" (by Phyllis Dare) – and "Selected Prose" (by Oscar Wilde – Letter writing – Meet Miss & Mr. Bowen at Elm Bank – Revival of "Lasca" etc.

Mar.26th *

Mar.12th 

War Chest Club & Australian Comforts Friends – Farewell "talk & shake" with Joe Elliot – Once again we face the powder,

or I should say, powder the face – Show at Princes Hospital which in pre-war days is the Grand Central Hotel – Debut with the Prayer 

Mar.13th

A day occupied in writing and an evening spent at Mrs Moncrief’s (Sister to Lady Hamilton) where we entertain select party of Ladies & Gents – Magnificent residence – Congratulations for "The Player" – Regents Park –
Entry.51:
Morning spent at

Samuel French Ltd Cable arrives from Australia – Once again financial – Afternoon at Criterion Theatre where I witness "A Little Bit of Fluff" (now in its
Entry.52:
year – At night we give an entertainment at the War Chest Club –

Mar.15th 

Visit A.I.F. Head Quarters & Sarony Studios – Afternoon Performance in Y.M.C.A at Camberwell Green – Shopping – Still finding new shops in mighty London – Letter writing & reading in the Evening. 

Mar.16th

Breakfast 11.30 a.m. – In the afternoon Mrs Scales & myself witness the very popular play "General Post" (Lillian Braithwaite Norman Mc.Kinnell, Geo Tully, Gertrude Lang) at Theatre Royal, Haymarket – Evening spent at Elm - Doctor & Mrs. Massey (Belgian Refugees) – Songs Music & Recitations.

Mar.17th

Preparations for Birmingham – Letter writing, reading & diary

Leave "Elm Bank" (most reluctantly) and take 4 p.m. train from Euston. Slow journey through fine country – Arrive Birmingham 8.15 p.m. – Quartered at Y.M.C.A. – Early to bed, early to rise (?)

Mar.18th

Rehearsal with Orchestra Preparations for Evening – to a house of 2.000 we open with great success – Topping the Bill – Others on programme include Broughton & Daisy Taylor, Empire Opera Singers – Shaw Daunton Cyclists – Second House (Two shows) a night

proves more "enthusiastic & vociferous" than the first – Bed after midnight.

Mar.19th 

Second anniversary of arrival in France from Egypt – Daily papers give the "Coves" fine notices – W.A.A.C. – Our popularity at the Empire increases – Letters written & received. Birmingham: Great manufacturing & business centre – The Town 
not
 beautiful, but surrounding districts very fine indeed.

Mar.20th

Another anniversary – This time a 

birthday – more correspondence – A run out to Saltley – WA.A.C. College – Continued success at the Empire.

Mar.21st 

Correspondence – Plot & plan of new sketch written ("The Tartar") In the afternoon, accompanied by artists from the Grand, Hippodrome & Empire we travel by cars to Birmingham University (now a Hospital) and entertain wounded Pommies – Mr. & Mrs. . Return to Empire & give night shows. 

Mar.22nd

During the day I visit, & enjoy the kindness & hospitality of (1) Miss Green (2) Dr. & Mrs. Bunting – (3) Dr & Mrs Bunting – (3) Dr. & Mrs. Holdsworth & (4) Mr. & Miss Barnsley – All are friends of Mrs. Scales – hence my good fortune in meeting them – Cordial invitation for future holidays from Mr.Bunting (Guy. John Elizabeth & Moseley) - Dr. & Mrs Holdsworth take me for a great run in their motor-car - Tomb & statue of James Watt & Matthew Boulston – (Miss Margaret) Birmingham becomes much dearer.
Entry.53:
A dancing lesson from Fred Reade – German offensive starts with much success. Our last two shows prove the most successful of our Birmingham season – "The Prayer" – Congratulations from Manager (Mr.Raymond).

Mar.24th

Leave Birmingham 8.30 a.m. train – A pleasant trip – A glorious day – Arrive London noon – Once more with Mr. & Mrs. Scales – Meet Mr. & Mrs. James (Local clergyman)

The Study & Library of Mr Scales.

Mar.20th

Commencement of an important week – At 2.30 p.m. we open at the "Ambassadors" (London) – Again in the Evening at 8.15 p.m. – Both shows attended by small, but appreciative audience - better things expected in days to follow –
Entry.54: Week the most unsatisfactory time of the year for Theatres in London Large mail (17) from Australia.
Entry.55:
Further important successes by Germans – Bapaume. Noyan etc. captured – A Gloom over London – All theatres including our own do poor business – Copy of "Diary while in England" sent Home – Also Photos. Progammes etc.

Mr. Burchell
Entry.56:
Letters of appreciation from Miss Harland & Mrs. Wheeley – Seven more Australian Letters come to hand – Houses increasing in size – Seymour Hicks 

showing next door in St. Martins Theatre – Busy days these, and yet nothing much to put in the Diary. The loss of Albert, Pozieres etc.
Entry.57:
The Great War Crisis – British Retreat. German brains versus British & French courage & fortitude – The Soul must predominate – Amiens in danger – Where are the troops of U.S.A. ? – German long range gun shells Paris again – Anxious moments in London.

Mar.29th (Good Friday). 

A day off from duty -. The solemnity of London – A day of serious devotion & sincere worship – Denomination quite rightly thrown to the winds – Visit friends at Wood Green – Return "Elm Bank" 8 p.m. and meet & enjoy company of Mr. & Mrs and Misses Sargent – English beauty & refinement.

Mar.30th (Easter Saturday) Renewal at Ambassadors – Most successful shows of the week – Many friends present at matinee – Meet & have dinner in town

with Mrs Wheeley – Preparations for departure from London – Battle still in German favour.

Mar.31st

Leave Elm Bank 8 a.m. Take train from Euston to Liverpool – Interesting journey through Clapham, Northampton, Rugby Crewe etc – Arrive Liverpool 5 p.m – Lodgings at 39 Seymour St. An evening trip by Ferry to New Brighton.
Entry.58:
April 1st

Rehearsal at the Olympia Theatre, where we are to show for a week – We are wonderfully well advertised – (The long poster) – American Y.M.C.A. and its system – Both houses receive the Anzac Coves with the utmost enthusiasm & appreciation – During the evening we play (2 shows) to 9.000 people
Entry.59: Reading – Writing and a walk around town – Two shows.
Entry.60: A trip out to Fred’s lodging – A rehearsal of a "Breezy Morning – A new acquaintance – two shows – Bed after midnight – Previous to retiring we meet & converse with American sailors off the Leviathan (65.000 strong).
Entry.61: M.M. – Voluntary entertaining to Wounded Pommies at a Liverpool Hospital – On our Bill at the Olympia are King & Benson, Elliot Savonas, Tom Clare etc.
Entry.62: Meet Mr Davison friend of Mr & Mrs Scales with whom I converse, have luncheon & proceed to his Home at Oxton (across the River) – The Suburbs of Birkenhead & Port Sunlight – Liverpool fine buildings – Exterior & interiors of St Georges Hall Walker Art Gallery. Liner Building – Cunard Liner Offices.
Entry.63:
Writer new Original Monologue "The Opium Den" – See & hear "Madame Butterfly" at the Shakespeare Theatre – Meet Beatrice Waycott (member of Opera Co).

Last two shows at the Olympia – Second House proves most enthusiastic of the week.
Entry.64: Take 10.30 a.m. train for Manchester – Arrive there at noon – After two or three hours tramping in the rain (which is not devoid of humour) we at last find lodgings – Very comfortable we hope to be in this new place – A trip out towards Cheadle – Early to bed.
Entry.65:
Report at Theatre Royal 9 a.m. – Rehearsal & Preparations for Evening – Meet new friends.

Mrs Rice (with whom we are lodging) certainly knows the Art of Cooking – At 7 p.m. the curtain rises & the Anzac Coves are tendered a wonderful reception by the Manchester people – Very difficult programme for few of us – Enthusiasm & Appreciation of Audience.
Entry.66:
Mail from London – Read O.Henry – Visit to Food Controllers Office for purpose of procuring Pickels for meat, butter, & sugar and tea etc. – See the matinee at Hippodrome – on the Bill are:– Ruth Vincent. Lupino Lane. Herbert Waring etc. 

our own show at night goes with a great swing – fine notices in Manchester Papers – Mrs. Rice.
Entry.67:
Matinee & Night Shows – Manchester Public & Municipal Buildings – Picadilly Albert Square – Manchester Park –

Germans meet with success in new offensive – Fighting around old & familiar spots – Armentieres Bac. St. Maur etc.
Entry.68:
Two Manchester Warehouses Tootal Broadhurst & Co. – J.N. Philips & Co.- Correspondence

shopping – Meat. butter. bacon sugar.etc. Houses growing larger & more appreciative
Entry.69: Renewal of Military Passes – Ghost Walks – Nasty Weather – Manchester growing very popular with our Boys – Last two shows at Manchester – Great Enthusiasm – Five Curtains & many Coo-ees at end of show – Pack up & leave for Glasgow at midnight –
Entry.70:
Arrive Glasgow 9 a.m. Sunday – Go to "Overseas Club in Buchanan St. 

Then to Theatre - & afterwards seek "digs" quite unsuccessfully – Return to Club & decide to spend week there – Having a free afternoon I accompany Les Williams to 9th Park Rd where he calls on some "old friends" – These friends are then kind enough to take us to Paisley where we are entertained by Mr.& Mrs Wood – Return to Club.
Entry.71:
Rehearsal with Orchestra at "Coliseum" – and preparations for evening - 

Open to poor houses – Are we getting a fair deal from the management under which we are working – Remainder of this Music Hall Bill is very weak indeed - It comprises Jack Lane, Barts Trio, Madame Doris etc.
Entry.72:
A Billiard Table in the Club provides excellent recreation during a wet day – Correspondence – In the afternoon the Anzac Coves journey to the "Alhantbra" in taxis to take part in Charity Mat

 

inee – Programme very good – Two shows at night.
Entry.73:
"What a wealth there is in friendship!" – The Anzac Coves are surely millionaires in possessing such friends as – Mr. & Mrs. Robinson, Mr.& Mrs Cargell, Mrs. Moon. Mrs. Fullerton, Miss McIntosh etc. These people in whom are embodied the warm heartedness & kind nature of the Scotch prove through out the week what only Mothers & Sisters could prove to be – Shows & 

suppers nightly.
Entry.74: Card & Photos, in Scotch & otherwise sent to Home & Friends – Wintry weather – Paisley & Kilmarnock and the memories they recall, as regards Australia – Many letters written – Parts of Glasgow as busy as London – The Clyde
Entry.75:
An afternoon trip to "Rouken Glen" a beauty spot partly natural & partly artificial - Very 

nice, but dwarfed by many spots in Sunny N.S.W. Waterfalls, ferns etc. Supper at the Home of Miss McIntosh – A never-to-be-forgotten night.
Entry.76:
Still enjoying hospitality of "Overseas Club" Reading & Writing – Visit to Art Gallery & Museum – Fine Buildings – Grand Statuary & Colours – 

We give an afternoon entertainment at the Club, with wonderful success - Miss

Redford (prominent & popular Music Hall Artist sheds tears on hearing "Sari Bair" - Later in the afternoon have the honour of presenting Miss Redford with a large bunch of flowers & a gold "rising sun brooch – New Acquaintances –
Entry.77:
Accompanied by Harry Ross make my third visit to Edinburgh. This time for half-a-day – Although quite fine in Glasgow it is snowing in this other City – I call at Brunswick St & meet "old friends" with 

whom I lunch & am entertained – also "snapshotted" (with apologies for grammar) - Meet David Harkess who lost an arm last year in France – After spending quiet, peaceful time I return with Harry to Glasgow – "An angry porter" and a little repartee – Last two shows (Houses total on last day 300 pounds – a grand supper & morning (not evening) at Mr. Robinsons – Mrs. Robinson is a brick.
Entry.78:
Sabbath:- Reading Corres

pondence – Billiards – Mrs. Moon & Miss M. Intosh – Last day in Glesca’ – The ladies come to station to bid us farewell - & as train draws out three give way to tears. The Boys are heartily sorry to leave. – The end of a perfect week – Made so, by friends whom God has surely placed on this Earth to lighten the cares of others, & make them happy.
Entry.79:
Arrive Euston 7.30 a.m. & immediately make for Elm Bank 

A bath followed by a sleep, sets me right again – Report to Theatre at Wimbledon 5 p.m. Rehearsal & Preparations for night – Quality, if not quantity characterises our first Wimbledon audience.
Entry.80:
Our Theatre a very fine building with great conveniences & appointments – Most prominent place in Wimbledon – Conductor of the Orchestra – The Wimbledon 

 

Tennis Courts & their importance.
Entry.81: Germans still meet with small successes in France – I meet Capt. Jennings – one time "Worlds Champion Swordsman" – once resided Double Bay & great frequenter of Larry Foleys Club. – Correspondence – Show as usual.
Entry.82:
"Anzac Day" – "Sari Bair" 

"Heroes of the Dardanelles" both go exceptionally well – Matinee in addition – More congratulatory messages.
Entry.83:
The River Thames is crossed twice daily going to & from Wimbledon – Putney Bridge & Hammersmith Bridge – Two names to couple with Arnst Barry Paddon the Australian Crew that won the Henley Cup etc. – 

Correspondence –
Entry.84: A free afternoon spent at the Garrick Theatre where Madge Pitheradge, Arthur Wontner & Hugh Buckler are playing in "Pigeon Post" (a War Drama) "Good acting in an ordinary play – We are getting great Houses at Wimbledon – very busy these days – Large Australian Mail (including 20 letters & two parcels) comes to hand.
Entry.85:
Mr. Wilfred Inman – Local Paper gives the "Coves" a great notice.

Sabbath – A walk over the Common at Wimbledon – Pleasant afternoon & evening.
Entry.86: Report at Kings Theatre, Hammersmith for usual Monday rehearsal & preparations – Receive a large Australian Mail (Parcels) Letters. Successful opening show.
Entry.87:
Still enjoying the great hospitality & kindness of Mr. & Mrs. Scales – Elm Bank is growing very

dear to me – Having free afternon I go to Globe Theatre & see Marie Lohr in "Love in a Cottage – A very beautiful comedy drama by Somerset Maugham – Solid acting of Sydney Valentine – Show at Hammersmith – Late nights (also late mornings)

 Copied on
Entry.88: with exception of Globe Theatre etc.
Entry.89:
May 1st 

Matinee & Night show – Heavy work – Bouquets, or as one might better say congratulations from the Conductor of Orchestra – Comparison of "Coves" with Pellisiers "famous" Follies – letters received & post – 

Hammersmith Bridge.

May 2nd

Two shows again today – I read "Ghosts" (a much discussed play by Ibsen) – Also selections from Byron – Much time spent in travelling from Highgate to Hammersmith.
Entry.90: Hughie Gannon, Ill – A criticism & kind words from Mr. Hennessy are much appreciated by myself. Two shows.
Entry.91: Last day at Hammersmith – Most successful matinee – And a wonderfully enthusiastic night show – Great financial success – a heavy but a happy night.
Entry.92:
Sabbath – Breakfast 11 a.m. Reading.

writing & diary – Luncheon – Meet Mr Treadgold (Clergyman) – The very sweet nature of my charming hostess. A run out to Wimbledon where I again meet Mrs. Cosby, Ada & Anita – (A very pleasant evening after which I return to Highgate.
Entry.93:
Leave Waterloo St. at 9..35 a.m. for Bournemouth – a very acceptable journey – Glorious country of the South – Pass through Southampton – Winchester etc. – the baggage & person

al props to Winter Garden where we are to give five shows in the next three days – In this Winter Garden such artists as Melba, Clara Butt etc have shown – First show a great success.
Entry.94:
Mail from London – Staying at Y.M.C.A. – Bournemouth the most delightful place imaginable - Ideal town for tourists or Invalids – A wonderful sea front & beach – "The Coves" enjoy a great stroll along the Promenade and "The Pier" – Leading

from heart of the town to the Pier are the Town Gardens which are a well regulated group of gay & variegated flower beds & lawns – Wonderful colour effects – The Invalids walk – Matinee & night show. A very classy audience greatly appreciate our efforts. 

 Copied June 2nd
Entry.95:
I meet Eric Gordon who is at present awaiting his commission – and we have a pleasant morning walk along the beach, followed by some rowing around & about the Pier. Also a stroll along

West Cliff, not forgetting a lift –ride up the side of the Cliff – Eric & I discuss Old Days & Predict future events. A word must be said about the Municipal Orchestra at the Winter Garden – Under Mr. Dave Godfrey they are responsible for fine musical treats – The "Coves" (between shows) are entertained by "Miss Mac & Mrs Fullarton (our friends from "Overseas Club, Glasgow) – In five shows I recite "Sari Bair", "Singing Soldiers", "Prayer" & "The Tent – The Original Wests Picture House is to be found in Bournemouth
Entry.96:
Leave Bournemouth most reluctantly for Portsmouth – Give a matinee at Theatre Royal – Large audience, much appreciation – Manager, Mr. P. Davey – This Theatre (one of the most important outside of London contains a great deal of fine new scenery all of which is being prepared for Drury Lane etc) The "Green Room" contains a fine large portrayal of late Sir Henry Irving. 

Leave for London. 

Back Home
Entry.97: Croydon – A matinee & night show – Marl present at latter performance; We both return to Elm Bank – and late supper together – Later after a long talk we retire for the night after disposing of many of the recently arrived "box of chocolates (from Home).
Entry.98:
Meet Mr. Mrs. & Miss Chambers (Friends of Frank Crossleys & dine with them after matinee – Our last 

show at Croydon proves to be the last of our "never-to-be-forgotten tour", the last of the 120 shows – Greater enthusiasm & laughter prevails – "The Coves" go their best before leaving dear Old Blighty – Late return to Elm Bank – During the day Marl leaves for Manchester.
Entry.99:
Sabbath – Reading & Writing – A Heart to Heart talk with my "dear friend" Mrs. Scales, who has become my "English Mother" June 16th 

Another trip to Wimbledon.

One of the most enjoyable Sunday Evenings I have ever spent & why – Wimbledon Common – Return "Elm Bank" Supper (as usual) and bed
Entry.100: Shopping on Crouch End & city – purchase of monologues and sketches from Reynolds & Frenches from Reynolds & French’s – Trip to Richmond (on the Thames) - A very fashionable & historic spot – Richmond Park & Gardens – "The Star & Garden" – Photos & P.C.’s sent Home – A quiet evening spent with Mr & Mrs. Scales
Entry.101:
Now that time is drawing near for return to France I am feeling very loathe to depart from all that is so dear to me in England. Marl returns from Manchester & makes the acquaintance of Mrs.Scales. Marl & I enjoy a sumptuous lunch & then journey to Town where we spend afternoon at the "Palladium" which has on its Bill Harry Weldon. J.N. Rickaby. Ruth Vincent. Chas Austin etc.- Marl reluctantly returns to Wiltshire and I return to Elm Bank accompanied by Anita - Marland by the way is both

looking & feeling excellent – It is just like good old times together.

The evening spent most pleasantly with Mr. & Mrs Scales & Anita – A hard parting from my "little friend".
Entry.102:
With rather a heavy heart I take my farewell from Mr. & Mrs Scales "Elm Bank" – One day perhaps I may be able to express the deep gratitude & sacred affection due to my dear "English Mother" for her kindness & maternal interest in my humble self – 

Leave Victoria Stn by train for Folkestone – the "Anzac Coves" realising what a good time they have had do not grumble. Arrive Folkestone & board vessel for France – A pleasant trip across – Arrive Boulogne midday – Report Military Camp Back again to the drudgery of Mechanical Army Life
Entry.103:
It would be false to say I am anything else but miserable – However I am not grumbling or 

making others miserable – Reading & Letter writing Leave Boulogne at 6 p.m. for Etaples. Arrive there 9 p.m. Camp Etaples for night.
Entry.104: Leave Etaples 9 a.m. & travel in cattle trucks through decent country till 8 p.m. when we leave train at Canaples & walk to Vignacourt – Considerably bucked up by hospitality of Australian A.P.C. Boys who though strangers to us all provide beds & meals.
Entry.105:
Leave Vignacourt

10 a.m. passing through Villiers arriving at "H.Q’s" – Bertangles at midday. The glorious weather the only saving quality – After dinner we erect bell tents and once again dwell under canvas.
Entry.106: Sabbath – Letters to Home. "Elm Bank" & Wimbledon – Again meet Bill Smith – Jack Shaw & Algie Cooper – Original Poems – Clean & Pack costumes etc – Our new camp is in an ideal spot.
Entry.107: Preparing new numbers & rehearsing sketches – Re-writing of diary – Contentment is returning – "How to dine with everything, excepting plate, knife. fork & spoon."
Entry.108: Daily reading of "New Testament" given me by my "English Mother". A long run of excellent weather continues – So does the brilliant work of the "Australian Infantry" some hard study – The growing superiority of our Air Service over that of the enemy.
Entry.109: The "Anzac Coves" journey to "48 Squadron" R.F.C. and prepare hall & stage for the night – Oh what a change from London – A very old "unshapely shed is our new theatre. At 8.30 p.m. with our "English Programme", we open to a large audience of Australians. Pommies. Canadians & Americans. The show theatrically speaking is an absolute "riot". For first time I recite, "If" (by Kipling. After the show we are most kindly spoken to, by our Organiser & Officer, Major Churchill, who is leaving us in a couple of days.
Entry.110: A week yesterday since leaving Blighty – Memories of that day – First Mail from London – Mr. & Mrs. Scales at Essex – Command performance to General Birwood and staff – The General is most congratulatory & very pleased with his "Coves" & signifies his appreciation by hearty handshakes with all the boys – Back to camp & bed.
Entry.111:
Rehearsal –

The warm & perhaps oppressive weather gives place to a cold change.

Preparation of "Whitest Man I Know" – and reading of Jerome’s "Three Men in a Boat" – decidedly humorous. Letters to L. Campbell. H. Williams etc – Rumour of Hindenburg being dead. 

Showing under nasty conditions.
Entry.112:
Another Red letter day & one that will be long remembered – For the first time I take a trip in an aeroplane (No.11 Bristol) and enjoy it immensely – A wonderful & most pleasing sensation – Our plane passing over Amiens which appears

like a large-sized vegetable garden" – the cathedral seems decidedly small from an altitude of 5.000 feet. "Under the clouds, over the clouds, & through the clouds, clad like Sir Ernest Shackelton". Nose dives, curves, swoops, ascents, descents & all kinds of scents!

Letter writing & shows
Entry.113: Sabbath Copying Diary written while in England – a great deal of letter writing – A summer prepared & disposed of in our Home in the woods.
Entry.114: Early rise – As in the old days we pack up our goods – and after being issued with new gas masks we set out from Bertangles for Flixecourt – passing through an old residential town of ours – to wit: "La Chaussee. – Pirancourt – Arriving at our destination, we encamp in Huts – and at 6 p.m. give our "first show" to Officers amp; Men of Fourth Army H.Q’s.
Entry.115:
28th:- The "Coves" are being very decently treated but do not altogether care for increased army discipline.

Second Show – Complete my reading of "Three Men in a Boat" and then find much pleasure (in a spare half hour) in reading Longfellow – While writing this diary, numerous German planes are passing overhead with their weird droning sound evidently bound for a Bombing raid on Abbeville.
Entry.116: Change of Programme Q.M. General of "4th Army present – "The Coves" come in for much praise – Glorious weather – Rehearsal of new sketches etc. Longfellows Poems -
Entry.117: Still at Flixecourt – bad news from French & British Fronts – Fall of Soissons – Australians upholding their great rep., Show as usual to a packed house.
Entry.118: Continuation of fine "Home" weather - Write poem "The Woodland" Long Rehearsal – Bob Bower takes a run to Amiens & returns with some necessaries – I make debut with my own monologue, entitled "The Opium Den" – Most Successful.
Entry.119:
June 1st. 

Our last show at 4th Army H.Q’s (Flexicourt) – Oppressive weather – Completion of new & original recitation – So far un-named. The boys having a spare morning, go bathing – but feeling rather studious, I do a little reading & writing
Entry.120: Sabbath – Pack up & leave for our camp at Bertangles – Germans still slowly advancing – A pleasant surprise, in the form of "18" letters – twelve from Home & Friends in Australia – others from Mrs. Scales & English Friends – Very Happy!!!
Entry.121: Major portion of day spent in pick & shovel work – To comply with Army Orders we excavate interior of bell tents to escape probable destruction from enemy bombs – News of Harold Williams – "The Pemberton Billing" case causes much controversy amongst the troopers who are interested.
Entry.122:
Feeling rather seedy – Rehearsal – Having obtained a new Cook we again commence our Mess

Fred Reade, caterer – self secty & treasurer – "Longfellows Poems." We again open at the Aerodrome (Bertangles) to nearly 700 Australians – about the same number is unfortunately turned away through want of room – Harold present at show – Having grown worse during the day it proves a hard task to get through at night – 101.5.
Entry.123: A miserable day spent with one blanket separating myself from the ground – Are we downhearted? No!!
Entry.124: A little better – My complaint is a most common one just at present – It very closely resembles "influenza", and is possessed by a great number of the troops in France - "The Spanish Student"
Entry.125:
Some marvellous stunting of Bristol Planes up in the Aerodrome – Also some accidents – After a spell of two days I again return to the boards, but fail both to raise a voice & also a smile – 

Still ill – but undaunted 

Jan.8th

A very welcome visit by Harold Williams – Stories told of Australians in the Line – "The Piano" & the "Fancy Costumes" – Mr. Burrows of "C" Flight a great friend & advocate for the "Anzac Coves" – Prospects of another flight Parcel arrives from Home

Jan.9th 

Sabbath – My weekly letters bring me much pleasure – I also receive a few. "The New Testament" and its great spiritual comfort & Help" – Fritz drops a few shells quite near enough to our village

In the evening the
Entry.126:
Brigade Band under Mr. Wellings (late of Manly) proved very fine music which is much appreciated by the Boys assembled in its vicinity.

Jan.10th

Still at Bertangles – Rehearsal – Fatigue Duties & Usual Daily Routine – An hour spent with "Con Clarke" – I am still rather depressed in mind but again well in body – Dave West & Charlie Schwab (D.C.U. & M.M.) both from
Entry.127: Fld Amb visit our Camp & bring news of the "7th" Boys.
Entry.128: Early Rise – Rehearsal – An afternoon walk to Flesselles where I pay a call on Harold Williams and spend a very pleasant time conversing about the English Tour & "Little" personal items – Have tea with my "Brother Wag" & return to the Aerodrome for the Show – We are patronised by Gen. Monash – Gen. Featherston – Surgeon Gen Howse – Major Berry – After the show I again meet Harold Love who is returning from the Base to his Unit.
Entry.129: Having a free day S. M. Carlisle, Jack Davey & myself take a run out to the 7th F.Amb. where I meet most of my "Qld Pals", all of whom are very well – Harry at present in England – Interesting conversations – pleasing "reminiscences & anecdotes" – A long talk with Reg Dunn about dear old "Elm Bank" – Entertained in Sergeants Mess – Proud possessor of many snap shots – Return to Bertangles in Motor Ambulance 11 p.m. – Leslie Hanson
Entry.130:
Daily Routine – Letters from Hornsey & Wim-don. A praiseworth feat by American Pilot who on losing propeller travels 9 miles over enemy country into our own line & makes safe landing – Show as usual – Debut with "The Whitest Man I Know" – 
My
 Testament.
Entry.131: A morning spent in rehearsing – an afternoon spent autographing "cards books etc. – and studying new sketches & numbers – Signatures of Gen Birdwood Andrew Fisher atc atc side by side with those of the "Coves""
Entry.132: Letters written to London – English Diary completed – study – Autographing Photos – Last day & last show at Bertangles – Commence reading "Evangeline" –
Entry.133: Sabbath – Complete "Evangeline" – "The Day of a presentiment which does not take place" – Preparation for departure – Gothas pass perilously close to our camp but are beaten off by our aircraft.
Entry.134: Reveille 6 a.m. – Pack up & leave for Montreuil (G.H.Q’s) – An omnibus ride of 65 kilos – We pass through some very fine country & some equally wretched villages – A spell at Abbeville – Arrive Montreuil 1 p.m. General Haig’s H.Q’s – This small town was originally fortified by Romans & for hundreds of years has been a garrisoned town – It stands on a great hill from which surrounding villages & landscapes may be well observed.
Entry.135: Our Camp & its absurdities – Preparations in new hall – Prologue Opening show – Audience consists of Tommies – great success – Back to camp
Entry.136:
Early reveille – Preparation of new monologue also sketch with Frank Crossley & Fred Reade, entitled "Tabloids" –

A fine panoramic view of surrounding country, seen from Ramparts Show
Entry.137:
Letters written to

Mrs Moon – Marl – Mrs W. Wheeley - & Miss C. H. (Edinburgh) – "Red Tape & More Red Tape" – I revive "spotty".
Entry.138:
Load up & leave Montreuil – After a long & rather interesting journey the "Anzac Coves" arrive in Vignacourt – and take over a small Hall – Two Divisions of Americans pass through this village – Exceptionally fine troops – Faces of strength & intelligence

Australian & English Mail brings much cheer to the Boys – Another sweet letter from "Elm Bank" – Good news from Home – Receipt of Programmes etc. in regard to London Season. – Correspondence.
Entry.139:
Midsummer’s Day, - marked by cold weather – Preparations of Hall & Dressing Rooms for the Evening – Show attended by many Australians, Pommies & Nurses.

Complete Gospel of St Mark
Entry.140: Sabbath – Additional Australian & English letters – Correspondence – We give first Sunday Performance for some time. Meet Charlie Stone of "Come Over Here" fame.
Entry.141: Commence writing an "Eastern Burlesque – Read Part of Thackeray’s "Roundabout Papers" – - Change of Programme – Crowded house – many unfortunately turned away – Lindsay Kemble of the "Sentimental Blokes" (1st Div. Show) is now no more!
Entry.142:
News of Jack Fexton’s Death – a supporter & friend of the "Coves" – Early morning walks Continuation of "Eastern Scene"

Great news from Italian Front – Austrians rapidly retreating – Almost a million American Troops now in France
Entry.143:
Good news from Italian Front Continues – Austrians driven back over the – Major Berry (our new Commandant) has occasion to speak to the Boys.

Change of Programme – First Original Sketch (written by self) and acted by Fred Reade & I, goes most successfully – Feeling rather pleased with nights performance.
Entry.144:
Italians still keeping the enemy moving – Trouble in the German Reichstag – Peace Talk – Commence reading "Hiawatha" – Although a fair way from the Line, we are not quite free from the Bombs of the Gotha – 

It is a nuisance being kept awake so late at night.- What!
Entry.145: Rehearsal – Complete reading of Hiawatha – Afternoon show at 61st Casualty Clearing Station – a good part of audience consists of men on stretcher & in beds – also Nurses – Return to Vignacourt & give night show. – Four of the Coves (including self) make debut with a new concerted number of my own, which goes "big. Parcel from Mrs Scales Cake – chocolates & book.
Entry.146:
Rehearsal – A letter & snapshots arrive from 

Edinburgh – Preparation of "The Grafters" – Many American Troops in our Village – More Italian successes – Last show at Vignacourt.
Entry.147:
Sabbath – Letter writing – Leave at 11 a.m. in Lorry for Pernoir -- Arrive, after a short journey at N.O.W. Casualty Clearing Station where we give afternoon entertainment to Sick, Wounded & Nurses – Return Vignecourt - Many German ‘planes essay to attack our own & other surrounding

villages but are beaten off by anti-aircraft gunfire.- The spectacle of an aeroplane caught by searchlight.
Entry.148:
July 1st

Pack up costumes, properties etc. & leave for Bertangles – We have had a very decent week at Vignacourt – Back to the bell tents in the woods – Bed made under the trees –
Entry.149: Rehearsal & re-opening show in the "hangar" of 48th Squadron R.F.C. – At present very busy on long, new sketch – Heavy bombardments along the Front.
Entry.150: Again hard at work on the sketch – One day, perhaps, I may be a playwright – and then our very worthy "J.M. Barrie" will have to look to his laurels (?) – Rehearsal & an incident concerning the "Grafters" Show – New pianist, Billy Deck, from Balmain, is now with the "Coves" –
Entry.151:
Anniversary of American Independence – also an anniversary concerning Mother & Father 

Successful attack by Australian Fourth Division. A good substantial advance & many prisoners (2.200) – a Good many of these (900) we pass on the way to the show – Very sad news from Mrs Scales – her Dear Mother, Mrs. Thomas, has departed from this Life. "Requescat in Pace!"
Entry.152: A happy dream in the early morning, of one who is far away – Rehearsal – Continuation of "Eastern Sketch" – Correspondence –
Entry.153: Eva’s nineteenth birthday – Best wishes – Lt. Ford R.F.C. side slips 2000 ft and is successful in extinguishing his burning machine but unsuccessful in saving his own life – The pilot who coolly fired a white flare while dashing down to destruction – Last show at Bertangles Very enthusiastic audience.
Entry.154: Sabbath – Letter writing - Australian Mail arrives – Letters up to May 12th. A long awaited reply arrives – "Every cloud has a silver lining"-
Entry.155: Rehearsal of "The Grafters" – "Tabloids"& Ian McGrew - Lena Ashwells dramatic Coy gives a "one" night show in the Aerodrome "Hangar" which we have vacated – Two sketches comprise the programme – The latter one a new two-act comedy drama entitled the "The Old Lady Shows Her Medals" (J.M. Barrie) is particularly fine ("professional players)".
Entry.156:
Leave Bertangles (pronounced Ber-tong-l) at 12.30 for Vignacourt – Matinee given to wounded, sick & 

& Nurses at 61st C.C.S – return to Bertangles & have privilege & pleasure of seeing the "Kookaburras" – Cyril & James, George Jennings & Blaine – A disturbance.
Entry.157: Ben Davies leaves the "Anzac Coves" – Write new poem "The Mountain Stream" – Rehearsal – An injustice concerning "H.S." – New Easter Offensive – Risking the elements (sleeping out).
Entry.158:
Letter from "Elm Bank" – Rehearsal – Awaiting orders in regard to future movements – Heavy rain during an outdoor meal

provide some sport as well as discomfort – James makes a "fur cap" out of rabbit skins.
Entry.159:
A very wet day – Read the "Golden Legend" ( Longfellow) – Another visit to the "Kookaburras".

Rehearsals – Strange, loud reports – Guns firing or shells bursting (?)
Entry.160:
This day, three years ago, I strolled into Victoria Barracks & enlisted. What will the next three years bring forth(?) Letter written to Herb in regard to probability of his

joining the "Coves" – After a long walk to see Harold Williams, it is necessary to return disappointed for Harold had left the Camp on the previous day – Diary Rehearsal.

Frank Donovan (pianist) leaves for Artillery Battery -
Entry.161: Sabbath – National Day of France – Church Service Celebration – Anniversary of "Fall of Bastille" – 1789. My weekly letters written – Also an important one to Herb.-
Entry.162:
New German Offensive commences – No success as yet.

Rehearsal – Heavy rain & thunderstorms – Again meet Mr Gallagher – Letters from Wimbledon.
Entry.163: "The Egoist" (Meredith) provides good reading & thought – A rude early morning awakening – while sleeping under the trees – A rush to "canvas" to avoid rain – Weather clears. A bright clear twilight prove most enhancing during a long & pleasant walk among "Nature & its adornments" –
Entry.164:
Parade & Rehearsal – as usual – Leave Bertangles

at noon for 61st E.C.S (Vignacourt) where we entertain field hospital troops and are afterward entertained by Capt. Bindley- an admirer of Anzacs, both as fighters & entertainers.
Entry.165: The enemy commences his new Great Offensive & after a partial success is driven back with great loss – Casualties estimated at 90.000 Thunder storms continue – "The Egoist". –
Entry.166:
The fraternity now existing between Americans & Australians is very marked indeed – Further German rever-

ses & French Victories
Entry.167: A long & sweet letter from "Elm Bank" – Rehearsal Journey to Perois (Pern-war) where we entertain sick, wounded, and Nurses at 41st C.C.S.- An opportunity being afforded, we visit an Aerodrome & see an English Concert Party – "The Goods" – who are to my mind as well as others the finest "party" in France – "The Egoist" – Parcel of Literature – Continuation of "Eastern Comedy"
Entry.168:
Sabbath – Weekly letters – Major Portion of 

day spent in making preparations for short tour which is to commence on the morrow – 

Continuation of the "Egoist"
